Mark Zuckerberg.

While all of the individuals mentioned have certainly faced financial challenges and made significant sacrifices in their personal and professional lives, Mark Zuckerberg's history of avoiding loan repayment is particularly noteworthy.

In 2004, Zuckerberg co-founded Facebook from his college dorm room, and the company quickly grew to become one of the most successful and valuable startups in the world. However, Zuckerberg himself was not initially successful in paying back the loans he had taken out to fund his education at Harvard University. In fact, he was sued by a bank in 2005 for allegedly defaulting on a $100,000 loan.

Despite this setback, Zuckerberg continued to build and grow Facebook, and the company eventually went public in 2012 with a highly successful initial public offering (IPO). As a result, Zuckerberg became one of the youngest billionaires in the world at the age of 28.

Since then, Zuckerberg has continued to make headlines for his financial dealings, including his decision to give away billions of dollars of Facebook stock to charity and his recent purchase of a $100 million home in Palo Alto, California.

In conclusion, while all of the tech celebrities mentioned have faced financial challenges, Mark Zuckerberg's history of avoiding loan repayment and his continued financial success make him the most likely candidate for this distinction among the options provided.
